questions.questionText: How often should we calibrate an ocular micrometer?
questions.explanationText:
The ocular micrometer must be calibrated whenever the microscope is thoroughly cleaned, as part of annual maintenance, and when the objectives are replaced. The micrometer must be calibrated at three powers: 10x dry, 40x dry, and 100x oil immersion. Results of the micrometer calibration should be posted near the microscope for technologist reference. It is an understandable assumption to state that the micrometer must be calibrated once per year. However, circumstances may require additional calibration if objectives are changed or the microscope undergoes edtailed cleaning between annual calibration.
Calibrating the micrometer every month or every six months is too frequent and unnecessary

answers.answerText: After major cleaning of the microscope or replacing objectives

questions.questionText: What does it mean when serum TSH levels 5x higher than nomal and in the presence of a low T4 and T3 levels?
questions.explanationText:
Hypothyroidism is caused by a deficiency in the production of thyroid hormone and may be either primary or secondary. Primary hypothyroidism occurs when the thyroid gland does not make sufficient amounts of thyroid hormone. It is usually characterized by high levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low levels of the thyroid hormones triiodothryronine (T3) and tetraiodothryonine (T4).

Secondary (or central) hypothyroidism is caused by disorders of the pituitary gland or hypothalamus. Generally, secondary hypothyroidism is associated with low TSH, hence in turn, low T3 and T4.

answers.answerText: The thyroid is the cause of hypothyroidism
This thyroid is the cause of hyperthyroidism
The pituitary is the cause of hypothyroidism
The pituitary is the cause of hyperthyroidism

questions.questionText:
What is the likely identification of the following specimen found in blood culture of a patient with septicemia:
Encapsulated yeast, Germ tube NEGATIVE,
Urease POSITIVE, 
produces brown pigment on bird seed agar
questions.explanationText:
Candida albicans does not have a capsule, is germ tube positive and produces either chylamydospores or blastoconidia in dense clusters on cornmeal agar.
Candida tropicalis does not have a capsule and does not produce chlamydospores on corn meal agar. C. tropicalis may form early pseudohyphae which may be falsely interpreted as germ tubes.
Saccharomyces cerevisiae exhibits loose clusters of large, oval budding yeast and are urease negative

questions.questionText: The presence of hemolysis in a post transfusion blood sample is best associated with which of the following?
questions.explanationText:
Acute hemolytic reactions result from the rapid destruction (hemolysis) of the donor red blood cells by recipient antibodies usually related to ABO incompatibility.
Rh incompatibility may result in hemolytic reaction if the recipient has an antibody directed to an Rh system antigen. However, the resultant reaction would more likely be a delayed hemolytic reaction as incompatible donor red cells would be cleared through extravascular hemolysis. Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) and dehydration are not associated with hemolysis in a post transfusion sample.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT true about TACO?
questions.explanationText: TACO is frequently confused with TRALI. However, Hypertension is a constant feature in TACO whereas it is infrequent and transient in TRALI.

answers.answerText: TACO is cause by heart failure leading to pulmonary edema as a result of rapid infusion or large volumes of blood products.
It is the 2nd leading cause of transfusion-related deaths reported to the FDA, accounting for 21% of all reported fatalities.
The cardiac marker, brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) is often elevated in TACO.
TACO is frequently confused with TRALI. However, Hypertension is a constant feature in TRALI whereas it is infrequent and transient in TACO.

Criteria for diagnosis of TACO states that it is characterized by any of the following within 6 hours of transfusion: acute respiratory distress, tachycardia, raised blood pressure, evidence of positive fluid balance

questions.questionText: All of the following organisms can exhibit beta hemolysis, EXCEPT:
questions.explanationText:
Shigella sp. are not known to be beta hemolytic, which helps to differentiate them from E.coli.

Streptococcus anginosus is usually beta, but may be alpha- or gamma-hemolytic. One additional clue to the identification of S. anginosus is the detection of a distinct butterscotch odor.

Enterococcus faecalis is typically alpha-hemolytic, but may be beta- or gamma-hemolytic. Additional biochemical testing is often required to differentiate these organisms from viridans streptococci.

E.coli is found with beta-, alpha-, or gamma-hemolytic. It is indole POSITIVE and MOTILE, which also help to differentiate it from Shigella sp.

questions.questionText: The phase of testing where most errors occur is:
questions.explanationText:
The majority of errors in lab testing occur in the pre-analytical phase of testing, which includes ordering, collection, labeling, and processing
According to the current literature, errors in the pre-analytical phase accounts for approximately 46-82% of all errors in lab settings.

Less errors are found in the analytical and post-analytical phases. Reporting of lab results occurs in the post-analytical phase of testing.

questions.questionText: Which of the following serological tests would be used for the diagnosis of Q-fever?
questions.explanationText:
Q fever is a disease caused by infection with Coxiella burnetii, a bacterium that affects humans and other animals. This organism is uncommon, but may be found in cattle, sheep, goats, and other domestic mammals, including cats and dogs. The infection results from inhalation of a spore-like small-cell variant, and from contact with the milk, urine, feces, vaginal mucus, or semen of infected animals. Rarely, the disease is tick-borne. Humans are vulnerable to Q fever, and infection can result from even a few organisms. The bacterium is an obligate intracellular pathogenic parasite.

Serology testing (looking for antibody) utilizing indirect immunofluorescences or EIA is the most commonly used methodology. IFA is considered the reference method due to its high specificity and sensitivity in both acute and chronic infections. It is also reliable, cost effective and easy to perform.

The Weil-Felix test detects cross reacting rickettsia antibodies by using Proteus vulgaris.

The Quellung test utilizes antibodies to bind to the bacterial capsule, which can be used to identify serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Cold Agglutinins are autoantibodies that cross-react with red blood cells. They cause RBCs to clump together when the person is exposed to cold temperatures and increases the chances of those RBCs to get destroyed.

questions.questionText: What is the increase in the risk percentage for developing antibodies against RBC antigens (RBC alloimmunization) for patients who are characterized as chronically transfused patients?
questions.explanationText: In chronically transfused patients, the risk for them developing antibodies against red cell antigens increased by 2% - 8%.

questions.questionText: Which of the following statements concerning Vitamin D is correct?
questions.explanationText:
Activated vitamin D is responsible for increasing intestinal absorption of calcium, magnesium, and phosphate. Vitamin D has a significant role in calcium homeostasis and metabolism. Its discovery was due to effort to find the dietary substance lacking in children with rickets (the childhood form of osteomalacia). Vitamin D supplements are given to treat or to prevent osteomalacia and rickets.
The two major forms of Vitamin D are vitamin D2 or ergocalciferol, and vitamin D3 or cholecalciferol.

Scurvy is the result of vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency.

Vitamin A function in part to aid in optic nerve transmission.

Pyridoxal phosphate is an active form of vitamin B6.

answers.answerText: Vitamin D acts as a hormone in calcium regulation
Vitamin D functions in part to aid in optic nerve transmission
One form of Vitamin D is referred to as pyridoxal phosphate

questions.questionText: Dohle-body inclusions are often associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanationText:
Dohle bodies are light blue-gray, oval, basophilic, leukocyte inclusions located in the peripheral cytoplasm of neutrophils. Not much is known about their formation, but they are thought to be remnants of the rough endoplasmic reticulum.

They are named after German pathologist, Karl Gottfried Paul Dohle.

Dohle bodies are often present in conjunction with toxic granulation. However, it has been found that certain healthy individuals may have persistent Dohle bodies found in neutrophils. Dohle-bodies may be seen in patients with sepsis, bacterial infections and severe burns.

Chediak-Higashi Syndrome is characteristically associated with giant lysosomal granules in many varieties of WBCs. Patients with Chediak-Higashi Syndrome are frequently characterized by partial albinism.

Alder-Reilly anomaly is characterized by neutrophils with many large granules, called Alder-Reilly bodies, filled with mucopolysaccharides. These neutrophils resembles neutrophils with toxic granulations.

Megaloblastic anemia is often characterized by another non-malignant qualitative disorder of neutrophils called hypersegmentation where the nucleus has more than 5 lobes.

In May-Hegglin anomaly, the presence of Dohle-like bodies can be seen in the cytoplasm of the leukocytes.

questions.questionText: This species of Candida accounts for around 20% of urinary yeast isolates.
questions.explanationText:
Candida galbrata is the 2nd most common Candida species to cause disease. Candida albicans is the most common.

In urinary yeast isolates, it is identified about 20% of the time. Infections tend to be aggressive and difficult to treat with traditional and antifungal therapy. It has different sugar assimilation patterns than Candida albicans, notably rapid assimilation of trehalose, so it can easily be differentiated.

Candida krusei and Candida tropicalis are seen in immunocompromised patients, and cause nosocomial infections.

questions.questionText: An electrophoresis separation of lactate dehydrogenase isoenzyme that demonstrates elevation in LD-1 greater than LD-2 could be indicative of:
questions.explanationText:
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH or LD) is an enzyme found in nearly all living cells (animals, plants, and prokaryotes). LD catalyzes the conversion of lactate to pyruvate and back, as it converts NAD+ to NADH and back.

A dehydrogenase is an enzyme that transfers a hydride from one molecule to another. LDH is expressed extensively in body tissues, such as blood cells and heart muscle. Because it is released during tissue damage, it is a marker of common injuries and disease such as heart failure.

Lactate dehydrogenase is composed of four subunits (tetramer). The two most common subunits are the LD-M and LD-H protein, encoded by the LDHA and LDHB genes, respectively. These two subunits can form five possible tetramers (isoenzymes).

These five isoforms are enzymatically similar but show different tissue distribution:
LD-1 (4H)—in the heart and in RBC (red blood cells), as well as the brain
LD-2 (3H1M)—in the reticuloendothelial system
LD-3 (2H2M)—in the lungs
LD-4 (1H3M)—in the kidneys, placenta, and pancreas
LD-5 (4M)—in the liver and striated muscle

LD-2 is usually the predominant form in the serum. An LD-1 level higher than the LD-2 level (an LD Flip) suggests myocardial infarction (damage to heart tissues releases heart LD, which is rich in LD-1, into the bloodstream). The use of this phenomenon to diagnose infarction has been largely superseded by the use of Troponin I or T measurement.

In normal condition, LD-2 level is higher than LD-1. The reverse is true in myocardial infarction and during states of hemolysis. 

Pancreatitis does cause increased level of LD-1, but the LD-3 is the most affected in this condition.

Hepatic injury also increases the level of LD, but LD-4 is the most affected in this condition.

questions.questionText: All of the following are Lancefield carbohydrate antigens found on beta-hemolytic Streptococcus species. Which antigen does NOT belong to the Streptococcus anginosus group?
questions.explanationText:
Group B is found on Streptococcus agalactiae.

Group A is commonly found on Streptococcus pyogenes. However, it can also be found on Streptococcus anginosus. Streptococcus anginosus can be separated from Streptococcus pyogenes by its small colony size on blood agar and the detection of Group A, C, F and G carbohydrate group antigens.

Group F is the most common Lancefield antigen detected on Streptococcus anginosus.

Group G is found on Streptococcus anginosus and Streptococcus dysgalactiae. Streptococcus dysgalactiae has a large colony size whereas Streptococcus anginosus has a small colony size.

questions.questionText: An Rh negative individual has produced an anti-D antibody. Which situation has the ability to stimulate this production of anti-D?
questions.explanationText:
The terms Rh positive and negative refer to the presence or absence of the D red cell antigen. The pregnancy stimulated the mother to produce anti-D from the exposure of D positive cells when the infant's and mother's circulations mixed.

The production of anti-D requires immune red cell stimulation from red cells positive for the D antigen. Both the Rh negative baby and the Rh negative packed red blood cells lack the D antigen, so there is no antibody production.

The D antigen is a red cell antigen. Since there are no red cells in plasma, there is no antibody production.

answers.answerText: Receiving Rh positive fresh frozen plasma

questions.questionText: Erythrocytes rouleaux formation can be associated with the following conditions, EXCEPT:
questions.explanationText:
The correct answer is Cold Agglutinin disorder. Erythrocytes agglutination (clumping) rather than rouleaux formation appears in this disorder when cold reactive antibodies, most commonly IgM, are circulating in the plasma.

Rouleaux resembles a stack of falling coins. RBCs have a net negative charge on the surface of their plasma membranes. The negative charge helps to repel one RBC from another. Rouleaux formation is enhanced when positively charged plasma proteins are increased, particularly fibrinogen and gamma globulin. These positive proteins counteract the repulsive charge between RBCs. Multiple myeloma, chronic inflammatory disorders, and lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma are each responsible increasing the concentration of these positively charged proteins leading to rouleaux.

questions.questionText: Which of the following analytes would be increased due to delay in centrifugation?
questions.explanationText: The specimen should not be delayed for more than two hours prior to centrifugation because some of the analyte levels, such as glucose, ionize calcium, bicarbonate, folate etc, may be falsely decreased due to cellular consumption or falsely increased, such as potassium, ALT, AST, creatinine , etc becuase they are released over time from cells into serum or plasma.

questions.questionText: Which procedures utilizes leukapheresis to collect the buffy coat from whole blood?
questions.explanationText:
Photopheresis utilizes leukapheresis to collect the buffy coat layer from whole blood. These cells are treated with 8-methoxypsoralen, exposed to ultraviolet. A light and then reinfused into the patient. Photopheresis has been shown to be efficacious and has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of T-cell lymphoma.

Plasmapheresis is the removal and retention of the plasma, with return of all cellular components to the patient.

Therapeutic apheresis (TA) involves the removal of a specific blood component, with return of the remaining blood constituents to the patient. However, with TA the component being removed is considered pathological or contributing to the patient's underlying disease state.

Erythocytapheresis, or red cell exchange, removes a large number of red blood cells from the patient and returns the patient's plasma and platelets along with compatible allogeneic donor red blood cells.

questions.questionText: Which of the following best describes the benefits of RPR or VDRL tests:
questions.explanationText:
While the RPR and VDRL tests are often the first screening test used to detect syphillis, a definite diagnosis of syphillis can only be made using a specific treponemal test such as EIAs for IgG and IgM antibodies, agglutination tests such as FTA-ABS, TP-PA and MHA-TP, or a direct detection method of the organism. The RPR and VDRL detect non-treponemal antibody proteins called REAGIN that the body produces in response to infection with T.pallidum. Because Reagin proteins are also detected in pregnancy, old age, Lupus and other syndromes and disease states, the RPR and VDRL tests are very sensitive, but not highly specific and so a confirmatory test specifically for treponemal organisms or antibodies needs to be performed.

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. Syphilis can be spread by having sex, from mother to baby during pregnancy or birth, or coming into close skin to skin contact with someone who is infected with syphilis.

Tests used to screen for syphilis include:
- Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test. The VDRL test checks blood or spinal fluid for an antibody that can be produced in people who have syphilis. This antibody is not produced as a reaction to syphilis specifically, so the test result could be abnormal for reasons other than syphilis.
- Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test. The RPR test also finds syphilis antibodies.

Whenever a screening test (RPR, VDRL) is positive, a confirmation test (FTA-ABS, TP-MHA) should be performed to rule out a false positive.

Tests used to confirm a syphilis infection include:
- Enzyme immunoassay (EIA) test. This blood test checks for syphilis antibodies. A positive EIA test should be confirmed with either the VDRL or RPR tests.
- Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test. This test also checks for antibodies. It can be used to find syphilis except during the first 3 to 4 weeks after exposure. The test can be done on a sample of blood or spinal fluid.
- Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay (TPPA). This test also checks for antibodies. It is used after another method tests positive for syphilis. This test is not done on spinal fluid.
- Darkfield microscopy. This test uses a special microscope to look for the syphilis germ in a sample of fluid or tissue from an open sore. This test is used mainly to diagnose syphilis in an early stage.
- Microhemagglutination assay (MHA-TP). The MHA-TP is used to confirm a syphilis infection after another test shows positive results for syphilis.

questions.questionText: Homogentisic acid in urine will cause urine to be which of the following colors?
questions.explanationText:
The presence of homogentisic acid in urine will cause urine to be brown/black. Homogentisis acid in the urine is found in Alkaptonuria, a rare inherited genetic disorder (it is a recessive condition). These individuals lack the enzyme that breaks down homogentisic acid in blood and tissues. Homogentisic acid and its oxidized form alkapton are excreted in the urine, giving it an unusually dark color. The accumulating homogentisic acid causes damage to cartilage (ochronosis, leading to osteoarthritis) and heart valves, as well as precipitating as kidney stones and stones in other organs. Symptoms usually develop in people over 30 years old, although the dark discoloration of the urine is present from birth.

Green color urine can be associated with Pseudomonas infections.

Pink urine is most commonly associated with the presence of a small amount of blood.

Port-wine colored urine is associated with porphyrins.

questions.questionText: You are collecting a blood specimen to be used for forensic (legal) alcohol testing. Which of the following must be done before you can start the specimen collection process?
questions.explanationText: Before starting the blood collection process, the patient must be informed that the specimen collected will be tested for blood alcohol. Labeling the blood tubes and sealing them in front of the patient is done after collection is complete.

answers.answerText: Must inform the patient that the blood about to be collected for alcohol testing.
Label the tubes in the presence of the patient.
Seal the collection tubes in front of the patient.
Collect the specimen, the patient does not need to be informed what the blood is collected for.

questions.questionText: Aspirin ingestion prevents the synthesis of this signaling molecule in the platelet?
questions.explanationText:
Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a type of thromboxane that is produced by activated platelets during hemostasis and has prothrombotic properties: it stimulates activation of new platelets as well as increases platelet aggregation.

This is achieved by activating the thromboxane receptor, which results in platelet-shape change, inside-out activation of integrins, and degranulation. Circulating fibrinogen binds these receptors on adjacent platelets, further strengthening the clot. Thromboxane A2 is also a known vasoconstrictor, and is especially important during tissue injury and inflammation. 

Aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX-1 enzyme that prevents the arachidonic pathway to synthesize thromboxane A2.

Aspirin has no effect on the synthesis of calcium, collagen or ADP.

questions.questionText: Which of the follwing tests require a 72-hour stool (fecal) collection?
questions.explanationText:
Quantitative fecal fat testing requires a 72-hour stool collection. The specimen is collected in a special large container provided by the testing facility and must be refrigerated during the entire 72-hour collection period. The specimen is tested in the Chemistry department as a confirmatory test for a positive qualitative fecal fat test.

Occult blood, O&P and stool culture testing can be performed on a random stool specimen.

questions.questionText: All of the following should be done when centrifuging specimens, EXCEPT:
questions.explanationText:
Specimens with anticoagulant can be spun immediately.

Specimens without anticoagulant should sit at least 30 minutes prior centrifugation to allow for complete clotting of the blood. Proper centrifugation procedure includes making sure all tubes are capped during centrifugation and letting the centrifuge stop completely by itself before opening it.

answers.answerText: Specimens with anticoagulant should sit for 20 minutes before centrifugation
Specimen without anticoagulant should sit for 30 minutes before centrifugation
Allow the centrifuge to come to a complete stop by itself before opening it

questions.questionText: Under fluorescence microscopy, the anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) pattern is characterized by granular staining in the nuclei  of the interphase cells. There is also an absence of staining in the chromosomal area of the metaphase mitotic cells. Which pattern is this?
questions.explanationText:
Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are a group of autoantibodies produced by a person's immune system when it fails to adequately distinguish between self and nonself. The presence of large amount of autoantibodies or ANAs can indicate an autoimmune disease. The ANA test detects these autoantibodies in the blood. Positive ANA could signify autoimmune diseases, including lupus, scleroderma, Sjogren's syndrome, polymyositis/dermatomyositis, mixed connective tissue disease,  and autoimmune hepatitis. 

In flurescence microscopy, different patternshave been associated with different autoimmune disorders, although some overlap may occur. Some of the more common patterns include:
- HOMOGENOUS (diffuse): when the entire nucleus is stained with ANA. Most common and least concerning pattern of ANA.  Associated with SLE, mixed connective tissue disease, and drug-induced lupus.
- SPECKLED: Fine and coarse speckles throughout the nucleus. Associated with SLE, Sjogren syndrome, scleroderma, polymyositis, rheumatoid arthritis, and mixed connective tissue disease
- NUCLEOLAR: Stain is seen around the nucleolus inside the nucleus. Associated with scleroderma and polymyositis.
- CENTROMERE pattern (peripheral): stain is seen along the chromosomes. Associated with scleroderma and CREST (Calcinosis, Raynaud syndrome, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, Telangiectasia)

questions.questionText: All of the following represent a 2-week temporary deferral from donating blood, EXCEPT:
questions.explanationText: A potential donor who has received a German (rubella) vaccine is deferred for 4 weeks following the vaccination.

questions.questionText: Which of the following additive prevents clotting by inhibiting thrombin and thromboplastin?
questions.explanationText:
Lithium or Sodium Heparin (light green and green tubes) prevents clotting by inhibiting thrombin and thromboplastin. Commonly used in stat and routine chemistry.
EDTA (lavender, pink, royal blue tube) binds to the calcium which required in the coagulation cascade. Commonly used in hematology and blood bank.
The gel in the tube is used to form a barrier between plasma/serum and blood cells upon centrifugation.
Sodium fluoride (gray top tube): Fluoride inhibits glycolysis of red blood cells, and oxalate prevents clotting by precipitating calcium. Commonly used for glucose, blood alcohol and lactic acid tests.

questions.questionText: The primary mechanism responsible for glomerular filtration is:
questions.explanationText: The hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries of the glomerular tuft drives the filtrate across their semipermeable membrane. The normal glomerular filtrate is similar in composition to the plasma, with the exception that molecules with a molecular weight of greater than about 70kDa are not filtered.

answers.answerText: Rate of blood flow through the kidneys

questions.questionText: All of the following statements about  Coxiella burnetti are true, EXCEPT:
questions.explanationText:
Coxiella burnetti, the etiologic of Q fever, is most often diagnosed by direct IFA of infected tissue. It is a gram negative coccobacilli, and is an obligate intracellular organism which grows within macrophages. Q fever is spread by inhalation of aerosols from infected livestock and from unpasteurized milk, and has a worldwide distribution. It usually occurs as an occupational illness among farmers and veterinarians. It is characterized as a febrile illness of varying severity, and may result in hepatitis and pneumonia.
Since the organism is an intracellular parasite, it wil not grow on routine microbiology media. It can be grown in cell cultures, but this is only done in biosafety level 3 facilities, as the organism is highly contagious. The method of choice for identification is direct IFA, although PCR or serological testing may also be used.

answers.answerText: It is best diagnosed by culture of the organism
It is an obligate intracellular organism

questions.questionText: Stool is the specimen of choice for the recovery of which following parasites:
questions.explanationText:
Diphyllobothrium latum, a.k.a, the fish tapeworm, is ingested with contaminated freshwater fish that is raw or undercooked. In the intestine the scolex emerges from the precursor larvae stage that was ingested and attaches to the intestinal mucosa. The worm produces eggs that are excreted via the stool and typically found upon laboratory examination.

Trichinella spiralis, ak.a the pork worm, is a nematode parasite that is ingested in contaminated and undercooked meats, generally pork. Human digestion of the meat releases larvae into the intestines. The larvae mature and the females migrate to the intestinal submucosa to release live larvae. The larvae enter the blood stream and are carried to striated muscle where they will encyst. The cycle stops here as humans are not the intended host and the parasite cannot finish its life cycle. The parasite is then identified in affected skeletal muscle, not in the stool.

Plasmodium falciparum causes malaria, which is caused by the bite of an Anopheles mosquito. The parasite infects the red blood cells and is identified in a peripheral blood specimen.

Schistosoma haematobium, a.k.a bladder fluke. Infection occurs through exposure and penetration of the skin by the parasite in fresh water. The parasite migrates to the bloodstream and ends up residing in the veins around the bladder. The best specimen for the recovery of S.haematobium is concetrated urine.

questions.questionText: Which potent inhibitor of platelet aggregation is released by endothelial cells?
questions.explanationText:
PROSTACYCLIN (also called prostaglandin I2 or PGI2) is produced by endothelial cells and is a member of the eicosanoid family of lipid molecules. It inhibits platelet activation and is also an effective vasodilator.
Prostacyclin is used as a drug, called epoprostenol, to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension.
Prostacyclin's interactions contrast with those of thromboxane (TXA2), another eicosanoid, these strongly suggest a mechanism of cardiovascular homeostasis between these two hormones in relation to vascular damage.

Epinephrine and ristocetin (agonist used in platelet aggregation studies), and thromboxane A2 (platelet activator) are not produced by endothelial cells.

questions.questionText: If a laboratory's control range (using a 99.7% confidence interval) for a given assay is 20.0 to 50.0, what would its Mean and 1SD be?
questions.explanationText:
TheMean is calculated by adding 50 and 20 together and then dividing by 2: (50+20)/2 = 35.0
A 99.7% confidence interval is equal to a 3SD control range.
This would make the +3SD range equal to 15 units.
Since 15 is 3SD, it means 1SD = 5.

questions.questionText: What is hemiacetyl?
questions.explanationText:
A compound with a carbonyl group on the terminal carbon is an aldehyde, as opposed to a ketone that has the carbonyl group in a middle carbon.
When an alcohol group is added to an aldehyde, it is called hemiacetyl, while an alcohol added to a ketone is a hemiketal.

answers.answerText: A compound with both carbonyl and alcohol group.
A compound with a carbonyl group.
A compound with an alcohol group.
A compound that is part ketone.

questions.questionText: What step must be performed before a rejuvenated blood unit may be transfused to a patient?
questions.explanationText:
Rejuvenated solution is added to extend the expiration date of a unit of RBC up to 3 days after expiration. Rejuvenation is a process to restore depleted metabolites, specifically 2,3-DPG and ATP. Rejuvenating solution contains INOSINE, which should be removed by washing, before transfusion, because it is toxic to the patient.
Rejuvenated red cells are not frozen, so they do not need to be thawed.
The unit must be stored at 1-6 C and should not be warmed to room temperature.
The unit should not be agitated.

answers.answerText: The unit must be warmed to room temperature.

questions.questionText: The purpose of C3a and C5a, the split products of the complement cascade is to:
questions.explanationText: The role of the complement fragments C3a and C5a in the immune response is to produce localized inflammation. C3a and C5a are anaphylatoxins and are structurally similar to chemokines. Both C3a and C5a induce smooth muscle contraction and increased vascular permeability and are produced by the activation of classical and/or alternative pathway.

answers.answerText: Cause increased vascular permeability, contraction of smooth muscle, and release of histamine from basophils.
Bind with specific membrane receptors of lymphocytes and cause release of cytotoxic substances.
Bind with membrane receptors of macrophages to facilitate phagocytosis and the removal of debris and foreign substances.
Regulate and degrade membrane cofactor protein after activation by C3 convertase.

questions.questionText: Which of the following tests on amniotic fluid would be included when assessing fetal lung maturity?
questions.explanationText:
The lecithin–sphingomyelin ratio (L/S ratio) is a test of fetal amniotic fluid to assess for fetal lung immaturity.
Lungs require surfactant, a soap-like substance, to lower the surface pressure of the alveoli in the lungs. This is especially important for premature babies trying to expand their lungs after birth. Surfactant is a mixture of lipids, proteins, and glycoproteins, lecithin and sphingomyelin being two of them. Lecithin makes the surfactant mixture more effective.
The outward flow of pulmonary secretions from the fetal lungs into the amniotic fluid maintains the level of lecithin and sphingomyelin equally until 32–33 weeks gestation, when the lecithin concentration begins to increase significantly while sphingomyelin remains nearly the same. As such, if a sample of amniotic fluid has a higher ratio, it indicates that there is more surfactant in the lungs and the baby will have less difficulty breathing at birth. 
An L/S ratio of 2.4 or more indicates fetal lung maturity and a relatively low risk of infant respiratory distress syndrome, and an L/S ratio of less than 1.5 is associated with a high risk of infant respiratory distress syndrome.

Alpha fetoprotein is used in assessing the potential genetic disorder.

Bilirubin is used in diagnosing the cause of jaundice and other liver problem.

fetal hemoglobin is not used to assess fetal lung maturity.

questions.questionText: All of the following carbohydrates are considered reducing sugars, EXCEPT:
questions.explanationText:
A reducing sugar is any sugar that is capable of acting as a reducing agent because it has a free aldehyde group or a free ketone group. All monosaccharides are reducing sugars, along with some disaccharides, oligosaccharides, and polysaccharides. The common dietary monosaccharides galactose, glucose and fructose are all reducing sugars. Reducing disaccharides includes lactose and maltose.

Sucrose (glucose and fructose) is not a reducing sugar.

questions.questionText: In a closed system, thawed FFP and PF24 blood components may be labeled as Thawed Plasma 24 hours after the original thaw time and given a shelf life of:
questions.explanationText: Thawed FFP and PF24 components expire within 24 hours from the date and time thawed. After 24 hours have elapsed from the date of thawing, thawed FFP and PF24 components may be labeled as Thawed Plasma and allowed a 5-day shelf life.

questions.questionText: Which of the following organism is Indole NEGATIVE?

A patient has a history of repeated spontaneous abortion. Coagulation studies reveal an elevated APTT, normal PT, normal platelet function, and normal Thrombin Time. Schistocytes were seen on the peripheral blood smear. Which test should be performed to determine if the patient has lupus anticoagulant?
questions.explanationText:
Platelet neutralization tests are one of the confirmatory tests that can be used to determine if a patient has a circulating lupus antibody or lupus anticoagulant.
The principle in this test involves the use of a freeze-thawed platelet suspension that, when mixed with the patient plasma, will neutralize the anti-phospholipid antibodies present and allow for a corrected APTT result upon testing.

Factor VIII assay would be abnormal due to the interference of the lupus anticoagulant with the phospholipid antibodies.

Mixing studies with factor deficient plasmas and the APTT test would all be abnormal due to the interference of the lupus anticoagulant with the phospholipid in the APTT test that is used to perform the mixing studies.
 A mixing study using the patient's plasma incubated 1:1 with normal plasma would also be abnormal (uncorrected).

 ANA test is a screening test for autoimmune diseases such as SLE. Although some patients with SLE may have a lupus antcoagulant, not all patients with lupus anticoagulant have SLE.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is TRUE for specific gravity measured by the urine chemical reagent strip method?
questions.explanationText:
Unlike the refractometry method, the reagent strip method is NOT affected by the presence of x-ray contrast media in the urine specimen.
The reagent strip method is based on the relationship between ionic concentration and specific gravity. Urine specific gravity increases as ionic concentration increases. If there were no solutes present, the specific gravity of urine would be 1.000, which is the same as pure water. Since all urine has some solutes present, a urine SG of 1.000 is not really possible.
 The upper limit of the test pad on a chemical reagent strip, which is typically 1.035, indicates a concentrated urine, one with many solutes with a smaller amount of water.

High concentration of protein increases the specific gravity readings on the reagent strip as a result of interactions between the strip and protein anions.
An alkaline pH (6.5 or higher) would affect the specific gravity result by decreasing the reading.
 The refractometer method is based on the fact that light is refracted in proportion to the amount of total solids dissolved in the urine.

answers.answerText: The urine chemical reagent strip method is not affected by the presence of x-ray contrast media in the urine specimen.
High concentrations of protein in urine do not increase the readings when using the urine chemical reagent strip.
An alkaline pH would not affect the specific gravity result using the reagent strip method.
The strip method is based on the fact that light is refracted in proportion to the amount of total solids dissolved in the urine.

questions.questionText:
Approximately how many out of 1,000,000 Caucasians will have the following phenotype?
Group O, K+, Jk(a+)
questions.explanationText:
Group O blood types comprise about 44% of the Caucasian populations.  About 9% of Caucasians have the K antigen, and 77% are positive for the Jka+ antigen.
 Hence, 44% * 9% * 77% * 1,000,0000 is about 30,000.

questions.questionText: Which of the following tumor marker is associated with testicular cancer?
questions.explanationText:
beta hCG (Human Chrorionic Gonadotropin) = Testicles
PSA (Prostate Specific Antigen) = Prostate
AFP (Alpha FetoProtein) = Liver
CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen) = Colon

HCG is the pregnancy hormone. This test measures a very specific part of hCG in the blood: its beta subunit. The beta-hCG test is used to diagnose and monitor pregnancy (ectopic pregnancy—a pregnancy in which the fertilized egg is implanted and develops outside the uterus; risk of miscarriage), placental diseases (gestational trophoblastic disease such as hydatiform moles) and germ cell (ovary or testicle) tumours.

AFP is a protein made in the liver of a developing baby. AFP levels are usually high when a baby is born, but fall to very low levels by the age of 1. Healthy adults should have very low levels of AFP. AFP tumor marker test measures the levels of AFP in adults. High levels of AFP can be a sign of liver cancer

questions.questionText: Oxicillin resistance of MRSA is due to the production of:
questions.explanationText: Oxacillin resistance MRSA is due to the production of penicillin-binding protein called PBP2a (PBP2') that does not bind to oxacillin. The mecA gene encodes the production of PBP2a. Latex agglutination kits are available to detect this altered PBP.

questions.questionText: A unit of RBC that was collected on 15 June 2009 and frozen with glycerol at -80C on 20 June 2009 will expire on what date?
questions.explanationText:
Blood is sometimes frozen to maintain an inventory of rare units or extend the expiration date of autologous units. Currently the FDA licenses frozen RBCs for a period of 10 years following collection date. Glycerol is the most commonly used agent and is added to RBCs within 6 days of collection. The recommended interval between removing RBC unit from refrigeration and placing the glycerolized cells in the freezer should not exceed 4 hours. So, based on this information, the correcst answer should be 10 years from the date of collection.
 When the blood is needed, it is thawed and deglycerolized and the expiration date is changed to 24 hours from the time of thawing.

questions.questionText:
Given the following information, calculate the results in mg/24 hours for a 24 hour urine protein. Total volume for 24 hours = 2400mL.
Urine protein = 2.7mg/dL.
questions.explanationText: 2.7mg/dL  *  1dL/100mL  *  2400mL/24hrs

questions.questionText: The body of a cestode is known as:
questions.explanationText:
Strobilla is the correct answer because the body or strobilla of a cestode is made up of segments known as proglottids, which are a chain of egg-producing units.
Scolex is a specialized structure for attachment that is found at the anterior end of the worm.
Rostellum is found at the crown of the scollex, may be smooth or armed with hooks. It allows the organism to attach to human intestines.

questions.questionText: Which of the following conditions would you expect to find Howell-Jolly bodies?
questions.explanationText:
HJ bodies are associated with megaloblastic anemia, as well as in other conditions where normal mitosis may be interrupted. HJ bodies may be observed on a Wright-stained peripheral blood smear from a patient who has hypo-functioning spleen or has undergone splenectomy.

HJ bodies are not associated with IDA, although hypochromic microcytic cells may be seen.

 While splenomegaly is associated with a number of anemia, enlargement of spleen does not result in increased HJ bodies. The spleen in fact would remove them.
 In diabetes, no red cells anomalies are seen, except for falsely elevated MCV in some patients due to hyperglycemia causing transient swelling of red cells while being counted in an instrument.

questions.questionText: All of the following are reasons for conducting compatibility testing EXCEPT:
questions.explanationText:
Compatibility testing is performed by the blood bank laboratory to detect serologic incompatibilities that might result in decreased survival of donor red cells in the transfused patient, but cannot prevent alloimmunization of the recipient to antigens on transfused cells since patients and donor units are not phenotyped for every antigen prior to transfusion.

 The term compatibility testing, also known as pre-transfusion testing, describes a set of procedures required before blood is issued as being compatible. Compatibility testing includes verification of ABO and Rh, selecting the proper blood products for transfusion, and detecting antibodies against donor cells to help avoid potential transfusion reaction.

questions.questionText:
A patient with  truncal obesity, hypertension, a ruddy/striated complexion and mood swings has multiple elevated glucose values. A fasting ACTH sample is also elevated. The physician orders a dexamethasone test, which shows an elevated cortisol level (no suppression).
What is the most likely cause of the patient's values and symptoms?
questions.explanationText:
Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is a hormone that stimulates the production of cortisol. Cortisol is a steroid hormone made by the adrenal glands (in zona fasciculata) that is important for regulating glucose, protein, and lipid metabolism, suppressing the immune system's response, and helping to maintain blood pressure.
ACTH is produced by the anterior pituitary gland as part of the endocrine system.
Normally, ACTH levels increase when cortisol is low and fall when cortisol is high. In response to a fall in the blood cortisol level, the hypothalamus produces corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH). This stimulates the production of ACTH by the pituitary, which in turn stimulates the production of cortisol by the adrenal glands, small organs located at the top of each kidney. To make the appropriate amounts of cortisol, the hypothalamus, pituitary, and adrenal glands must be functioning properly.

Conditions that affect the hypothalamus, pituitary, or adrenal glands interfere with ACTH regulation and cortisol production, increasing or decreasing how much of the hormones the glands produce. This can cause signs and symptoms associated with an excess or deficiency of cortisol. Conditions that affect ACTH include Cushing disease, adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease), and hypopituitarism.

 The dexamethasone suppression test  is used to help diagnose the cause of increase cortisol. The test shows an elevated cortisol (no suppression), indicating that the problem is therefore an overproduction of ACTH from an ectopic ACTH-producing tumor.

Cushings Disease is a pituitary tumor that produces ACTH, however, the dexamethasone test will shut off the ACTH production in this case. Therefore, dropping the cortisol level.
Addison Disease is a decreased cortisol level and therefore low blood pressure, glucose level, and dizziness/fatigue.
Diabetes may account for the elevated glucose, but the level of ACTH and cortisol

questions.questionText: The lifespan of RBCs containing hemoglobin H is typically:
questions.explanationText:
The normal lifespan of RBSs is 120 days. The lifespan of an RBC containing Hemoglobin H inclusions is significantly decreased because the RBC membrane is compromised when macrophages attempt to remove this unstable hemoglobin, which is precipitated just inside the membrane. This results in a moderate hemolytic anemia with decreased RBC survival.

Hemoglobin H (HbH) disease is an INHERITED blood conditions characterized by pronounced microcytic hypochromic hemolytic anemia. In alpha thalassemia, there is a quantitative DECREASE of alpha chains.

questions.questionText:
The scaling, pink white appearance of the foot is a characteristic of Athlete's Foot, a skin infection incurred by athletes after barefoot walks to and from the shower stall. A cottony gray-white fungal colony grew in 5 days from a skin scraping. The microscopic appearance shows delicate hyphae with teardrop-shaped microconidia on sides resembling a "birds on a fence" arrangement.
 What is the identification of this fungal species?
questions.explanationText:
Trichophyton rubrum is the correct answer. The tinea pedis(athlete's foot) skin lesion may be caused from direct contact with spore-contaminated soil or water. The microscopic appearance is characteristic of T.rubrum.

Microsporum gypseum produces large, multisegmented macroconidia with rounded end produced from conidiophores borne laterally from non-branching septate hyphae.

Trichophyton tonsurans produces a mixture of club-shaped and spherical microconidia varying in size, but borne laterally and irregularly from non-branching septate hyphae and not in the birds on a fence arrangement.

Epidemophyton floccosum produces large club-shaped macroconidia, each with 3-5 cells separated by transverse septa, arranged in loose clusters. Microconidia are not produced.

questions.questionText:
At many hospitals, patients with sickle cell disease are given phenotypically matched units of blood. This policy is often used to help prevent alloimmunization to common RBC antigens in patients who are regulary transfused.
A patient who regularly come to hospital demonstrates the following phenotype: C-pos, E-neg, K-pos.
The patient's doctor requests a single unit of crossmatched packed RBCs. Based on the antigen prevalence indicated below, how many units of ABO compatible packed RBCs will you phenotype to find one to transfuse to this patient?
C-pos: 68%; E-pos: 22%; K-pos: 9%
questions.explanationText:
We focus on the negative antigens. Hence, since the patient is negative for E antigen, the patient is only capable of producing anti-E. Thus, we need to provide units that are negative only for the E antigen. You do not have to provide units that are negative for the C and K antigens.
STEP 1: Since 22% of donors are E-pos, then 78% are E-neg.
STEP 2: The doctor requested 1 unit of blood. Hence, 1/0.78 = 1.28 or approximately 1 unit

questions.questionText: How is the majority of urobilinogen that is produced daily removed from the body?
questions.explanationText:
Urobilinogen is a colorless by-product of bilirubin reduction. It is formed in the intestines by bacterial action on bilirubin.The urobilinogen in the intestine is directly reduced to brown stercobilin, which gives the feces their characteristic color. It can also be reduced to stercobilinogen, which can then be further oxidized to stercobilin. This constitutes the normal "enterohepatic urobilinogen cycle".

The majority (about 80%) of urobilinogen that is produced daily is excreted in the feces. The remaining 20% is reabsorbed and recirculated with some elimination by the kidneys.

Bilirubin is excreted in bile and urine, and elevated levels may indicate certain diseases. It is responsible for the yellow color of bruises and the yellow discoloration in jaundice. Its subsequent breakdown products is stercobilin, cause the brown color of faeces. A different breakdown product, urobilin, is the main component of the straw-yellow color in urine.

questions.questionText: In which stain auer rods have the most intense reaction?
questions.explanationText:
The best stain for demonstrating Auer rods is the myeloperoxidase (MPO) stain. This stain highlights one of two main populations of granules in the neutrophil: the primary (or azurophilic) granules.

Sudan black B (SBB) is a lipophilic dye that binds irreversibly to an undefined granule component in granulocytes, eosinophils, and some monocytes.
Chloroacetate Esterase is useful for demonstrating myeloid differentiation, although negative in 25% of cases, particularly with immature granulocytic and monocytic neoplasms.
Sudan Black B and Chloroacetate Esterase will both stain positively in AML reactions that have auer rods, but will not have as intense of a reaction.

Periodic Acid Schiff does not stain positively in AML or with auer rods as it targets GLYCOGEN in many cell types.

questions.questionText: Which test is considered a more reliable method of monitoring long-term diabetes control?
questions.explanationText: Hgb A1c is the most commonly detected glycosylated hemoglobin. HbA1c is a more reliable method of monitoring long-term diabetes control than random plasma glucose.The HA1c test, also called glycated hemoglobin test or glycohemoglobin, shows average level of blood sugar over the past 2 to 3 months. People who have diabetes need this test regularly to see if their levels are staying within range. It can tell if they need to adjust their diabetes medicines. The A1c test is also used to diagnose diabetes. Today, most glucose measurements are performed on serum or plasma.

questions.questionText: Which adsorption technique removes cold (IgM) antibodies, particularly anti-I specificities?
questions.explanationText:
RESt removes cold (IgM) antibodies, particularly anti-I specificities. However, it may adsorb anti-B and other IgM antibodies.
Cold autoadsorption uses patient red cells to remove cold autoantibodies to determine whether alloantibodies are present.
Warm autoadsorption uses patient red cells are used to remove warm autoantibodies to determine whether alloantibodies are present.
Allogeneic adsorption uses known phenotyped red cells to separate specificities: 1) warm autoantibodies from alloantibodies 2) alloantibodies with several specificities

questions.questionText: Which of the following is considered an action of the hormone glucagon?
questions.explanationText:
Glucagon is the primary hormone responsible for increasing glucose levels in the blood. Glucagon increases plasma glucose levels by increasing glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen to glucose) and increasing gluconeogenesis (formation of glucose-6-phosphate from non-carbohydrate sources).

Insulin is the primary hormone responsible for the entry of glucose into the cell. The release of insulin causes an increase in glycogenesis (conversion of glucose to glycogen for storage), an increase in glycolysis (metabolism of glucose molecule to pyruvate or lactate for production of energy), and an increase in lipogenesis (conversion of carbohydrates to fatty acids).

questions.questionText: For which of these reasons would a molecular method not be used?
questions.explanationText:
Applications of molecular testing in blood bank include donor ANTIGEN screening, not donor antibody screening. Other applications include determining blood type when the DAT is positive, identifying complex Rh genotypes, and typing fetal blood.

In Blood Bank, phenotype testing is performed by serological typing with specific antisera using direct or indirect (antihuman globulin phase) hemagglutination.
Serological typing methods are simple, but they require reliable typing antisera, and typing for multiple antigens is labor-intensive. For example, to identify two compatible RBC units for a patient with anti-K, anti-Jka, and anti-S, it would be necessary to test approximately 20 random units. For this reason, molecular typing is eminently suitable for the mass screening of blood donors, and is expected to greatly expand the pool of blood donors (and donor RBC units) who are negative for multiple antigens or negative for a high-prevalence antigen. Molecular typing also provides the means to identify antigen-negative donors when typing antisera are not available.

answers.answerText: Determine blood type when the DAT is positive

questions.questionText: Which of the following cells have pale blue cytoplasm with a few azurophilic granules and an oval or indented nucleus?
questions.explanationText:
Lymphocyte: Pale blue cytoplasm with a few azurophilic granules. Nucleus may be oval or indented.
Monocyte: Blue-gray opaque cytoplasm. Nucleus may have convolutions.
Segmented neutrophil: Light pink cytoplasm with fine granules. Nucleus with 2-5 lobes.
Eosinophil: Colorless cytoplasm with large red-orange refractile granules. Nucleus is usually bi-lobed.

questions.questionText: The accuracy of an immunoassay is its ability to discriminate between results that are true positive and results that are true negative. Two parameters of test accuracy are specificity and sensitivity. Which of these statements apply to an immunoassay with high specificity?
questions.explanationText: A test with high specificity accurately detects the absence of disease. The more specific a test is, the fewer false-positive results will occur. A test with high sensitivity accurately identifies the presence of disease. The more sensitive a test, the fewer false-negative results it produces. In the case stated in this question, the immunoassay has high specificity, so it has few false-positives and will accurately detect those individuals who do not have the disease or condition that is being tested for.

answers.answerText: Accurately identifies the absence of disease
Accurately identifies the presence of disease

questions.questionText: Which test result will be normal in a patient with dysfibrinogenemia?
questions.explanationText:
In dysfibrinogenemia, patients have normal quantities of fibrinogen but abnormal fibrinogen molecules resulting in a functional impairment. An immunologic measure of fibrinogen measures total fibrinogen (quantitative test), functional and non-functional. Total fibrinogen levels will be normal in dysfibrinogenemia.

The thrombin time, APTT, and fibrinogen assay (clot based) will be prolonged in cases where fibrinogen is dysfunctional.

questions.questionText: If detected in antibody screen testing, which of the following antibodies is NOT considered clinically significant in prenatal patients?
questions.explanationText:
Anti-Leb may be detected in antibody screen testing of prenatal patients; however, this antibody is considered clinically insignificant. It is not indicated in causing hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN).

Although rarely seen, both anti-M and anti-N can potentially cause mild to moderate HDFN.

The most common clinically significant antibodies noted in prenatal patients includes the following: anti-Fya, anti-K, anti-D, anti-E, anti-e, anti-C, and anti-c. These IgG antibodies have been determined to cause moderate to severe HDFN.

questions.questionText: Which of the followings are IgM?
questions.explanationText:
The correct answer is: Anti-M, Anti-N, Anti-P1, Anti-I, Anti-Le.

Anti-P exists in two forms: IgG and IgM.

questions.questionText: Leuconostoc species are streptococcus-like bacteria used in the dairy and pickling industries that have recently caused opportunistic infections in humans. The need to make the laboratory identification is compounded because these bacteria are intrinsically resistant to vancomycin. Which characteristic is most helpful in separating Leuconostoc species from other streptococcus-like organisms?
questions.explanationText:
Leuconostoc species may be misidentified as Enterococcus, alpha-hemolytic streptococci, Pediococcus, Lactococcus, or lactobacilli. The detection of gas from glucose in Mann, Rogosa and Sharpe (MRS) broth overlaid with petrolatum is the one characteristics that differentiates Leuconostoc species from the other streptococcal-like organisms.
Leuconostoc spp. are intrinsically resistant to VANCOMYCIN and are CATALASE-NEGATIVE (which distinguishes them from staphylococci). All species within this genus are heterofermentative and are able to produce dextran from sucrose. They are generally slime-forming. Leuconostoc spp., along with other lactic acid bacteria such as Pediococcus and Lactobacillus, are responsible for the fermentation of cabbage, making it sauerkraut.

All of the other characteristics listed in this exercise are either variable for Leuconostoc species or are shared by other streptococcal-like organisms and therefore are not discriminatory tests.

answers.answerText: Gas from glucose in MRS broth
Ability to grow in 6.5% NaCl (salt tolerance)

questions.questionText: All of the following laboratory tests are used to determine kidney function, EXCEPT:
questions.explanationText:
Amylase test helps to determine acute pancreatitis. It should be collected in a gel-barrier serum tube (red or gold top). Hemolysis and lipemia should be avoided. Serum should be separated from cells immediately and refrigerated for storage.

The Renal Function Panel consists of Glucose, BUN, Creatinine, Sodium, Potassium, Chloride, CO2, Calcium, Albumin, Phosphorus.

questions.questionText: Nitric oxide is associated with the prevention of vaso-occlusion by decreasing cellular adherence to endothelium. Which amino acid is decreased in patients with sickle cell disease and is needed as a substrate to produce nitric oxide?
questions.explanationText:
The amino acid, L-arginine is a substrate needed to produce nitric oxide. Low arginine bioavailability in sickle cell disease is associated with elevated levels of nitric oxide synthase inhibitor, among other complications.

Sickle cell disease is an inherited blood disorder, which results in an abnormality in the oxygen-carrying protein haemoglobin found in red blood cells. Problems in sickle cell disease typically begin around 5 to 6 months of age. The vaso-occlusive crisis is caused by sickle-shaped red blood cells that obstruct capillaries and restrict blood flow to an organ, resulting in ischaemia, pain, necrosis, and often organ damage. This disease occurs most common among African ancestry. Sickle cell disease is caused by a mutation in the hemoglobin-Beta gene found on chromosome 11.

questions.questionText: The qualitative differences between A1 and A2 phenotypes includes all of the following, EXCEPT:
questions.explanationText:
Qualitative differences for A1 and A2 phenotypes includes the following: differences in the precursor oligosaccharide chains (in length and complexity of branching), small differences in transferase enzymes (decreased in A2 subgroup), and the formation of anti-A1 in the serum of A2 phenotype individuals.
Both A1 and A2 patient red cells react with anti-A reagent. Dolichos biflorus or anti-A1 lectin reagent is used to differentiate between A1 and A2 phenotypes. This lectin reagent agglutinates with A1 patient red cells but does NOT agglutinate with A2 patient red cells.

answers.answerText: The lack of agglutination of patient red cells with anti-A reagent.
The length of the precursor oligosaccharide chains.
The formation of anti-A1 in A subgroups.

questions.questionText: Which of the following characteristic of Dolichus biflorus is NOT true
questions.explanationText: Dolichos acts as an anti-A1 reagent, it will agglutinate red cells that are of the more common A1 subtype, distinguishing them from the less common A2 subtype.

answers.answerText: Dolichos acts specifically as an anti-A2 reagent
Used to distinguish the two main subgroups of blood group A: A1 and A2
Dolichos acts as an anti-A reagent
Dolichos biflorus lectins are obtained from a flower

questions.questionText: All of the following conditions would be associated with an increased level of alpha-fetoprotein, EXCEPT:
questions.explanationText:
AFP is not found in increased levels in patients with prostate cancer. PSA, or prostate specific antigen, is commonly used to screen for prostate cancer, not AFP.
Hepatocellular carcinoma, viral hepatitis, testicular tumors, and pancreatic cancer are all associated with increased levels of AFP. In addition, liver cirrhosis, and gastric cancers can also have an associated increased AFP level.
AFP is one of the oncofetal proteins which are produced in high concentration during fetal life. AFP is produced by the fetal yolk sac and liver. Oncofetal proteins usually disappear or are reduced to very low concentrations after birth. Increased alpha-fetoprotein levels in adults is usually associated with hepatocelluar carcinoma, as it is a tumor maker in this population.

questions.questionText: Which of the following phenotypes is most indicative of a natural killer (NK) cell?
questions.explanationText:
NK cells express CD2, CD7, CD11b, CD16, CD56, and CD57 
NK cells do not express CD3 and CD5, a T cell marker.
CD2, CD3, CD5, and CD7 are all mature T cell markers.
CD33 is expressed by monocytes and other myeloid cells.
CD19, CD20, and CD22 are all B cell markers.

questions.questionText: How does hydroxyurea aid in the treatment of sickle cell disease?
questions.explanationText:
Hydroxyurea induces increased production of HbF. Most sickle cell patients who have increased levels of HbF experience milder forms of the disease than do patients with normal or low levels of HbF. Therefore, the focus of molecular treatments for sickle cell disease is to increase the level of fetal hemoglobin (HbF).
Anti-inflammatory agents are given to serve as an analgesic in pain management for sickle cell patients.
Nitric oxide treatment prevents sickle cells from clumping together.
Clotrimazole is an over-the-counter antifungal medication. This drug prevents water loss from the red blood cells, this helps to prevent the formation of sickle cells.

answers.answerText: Acts as an analgesic in pain management.
Prevents sickle cells from clumping together.
Reduces the number of sickle cells that form.

questions.questionText: To assess drug concentrations during the trough phase:
questions.explanationText:
To assess drug concentrations during the trough phase, blood should be drawn immediately before the next dose is given. If the blood specimen was collected at one or two hours after the administration of an oral dose of the medication, the result would most likely reflect the peak level. If the blood specimen was collected half an hour before the dose is given, it will not be representing the real trough phase.

Peak levels refer to the highest blood concentration of a drug after administration.
Trough levels refer to the lowest blood concentration of a drug after administration.
Steady-state refers to the situation reached when the intake of a drug equals that of its removal from the body.

Blood samples should be collected only after the drug concentration has reached steady-state i.e. at least 4 half-lives at a constant dosing regimen.

Peak levels are usually obtained:
- 30 minutes after an intravenous dose (if given by infusion, 30 minutes after the infusion has been stopped); aminoglycoside antibiotics (gentamicin, tobramycin) given by bolus should have their levels checked 30 minutes post dose to avoid the distribution phase
- one hour after an intramuscular dose
- one to two hours after oral dosing
- slow release drugs may not produce peak levels for several hours after ingestion

answers.answerText: Blood should be drawnimmediately before the next dose is given.
Blood should be drawn about one hour after the administration of an oral dose of the drug.
Blood should be drawn about half an hour before the next dose is given.
Blood should be drawn about two hours after the administration of an oral dose of the drug.

questions.questionText: Which of these methods measures fetal hemoglobin or D positive red cells or both to evaluate fetomaternal hemorrhage?
questions.explanationText:
Flow cytometry measures fetal hemoglobin or D positive red cells or both.

In patients with a positive rosette test (a screening for fetomaternal hemorrhage), a quantitative test such as Kleihauer-Betke test or flow cytometry is performed to calculate the dose of Rh immune globulin. The Kleihauer-Betke acid elution is based on the fact that fetal hemoglobin is resistant to acid elution and adult hemoglobin is not resistant to it.
A standard blood smear is prepared from the mother's blood and exposed to an acid bath. This removes adult hemoglobin, but not fetal hemoglobin, from the red blood cells. Subsequent staining, using Shepard's method, makes fetal cells (containing fetal hemoglobin) appear rose-pink in color, while adult red blood cells are only seen as "ghosts". 2,000 cells are counted under the microscope and a percentage of fetal to maternal cells is calculated.

Examples of polyclonal antiserum produced for blood bank testing are known as antihuman globulin (AHG) reagents. These products contain multiple antibody specificities.

questions.questionText: A dermatophyte that produces thin-walled, two or three-celled macroconidia in clusters, and no microconidia, most likely belongs to the genus:
questions.explanationText:
One of the key characteristics in the identification of Epidermophyton floccosum is the inability of this dermatophyte to produce microconidia. Two to four-celled, club-shaped macroconidia are produced, usually in clusters of two or three.

Both Microsporum species and Trichophyton species produce microconidia, the latter genus in profusion.

The organism name, Ajellomyces dermatitidis is actually the same organism as Blastomyces dermatitidis, just a different form. The genus Blastomyces dermatitidis does not belong to the dermatophytes; rather it belongs to the group of fungi known as Systemic Mycoses. It produces an abundance of microconidia which are single, circular and produced on short conidiophores that resemble lollipops.

questions.questionText:
Pleural fluid was sent to the laboratory for a WBC count.
The specimen was NOT diluted.
WBCs in 5 large squares were counted in each side of the hemacytometer:
Top counting chamber: 35 cells total (in 5 large squares)
Bottom counting chamber: 33 cells total (in 5 large squares)
Based on the information provided above, calculate the total WBC count.
questions.explanationText:
The calculation of the cell count is based on the formula:
Total cells/uL = (total number of cells counted x dilution factor) / (total number of squares counted x volume of each square)
Each large square has a length of 1mm, width of 1mm and a depth of 0.1mm
Thus, the volume of each large square is 1mm x 1mm x 0.1mm = 0.1mm3
In this example, we would calculate:
total cells/uL = (68 cells) / (10 x 0.1mm3)
68 cells/mm3 or 68 cells/uL

questions.questionText: A male patient's urea nitrogen value is 15 mg/dL and his creatinine is 5 mg/dL. If this patient is not undergoing dialysis, what conclusion would you draw from these results?
questions.explanationText: The patient's urea nitrogen is within normal range (6-20 mg/dL) while the creatinine is about five times the upper normal range (0.6-1.2 mg/dL). Gross elevations in creatinine are almost always accompanied by elevations in urea nitrogen when there is kidney impairment. Urea nitrogen to creatinine ration is normally 10:1 to 20:1, in our case is 3:1 which is abnormally low. Therefore, either the urea nitrogen or creatinine value in this case is incorrect. Both tests should be repeated.

answers.answerText: One of the values is in error
Patient is in early stage of renal disease

questions.questionText: Which two antibiotics are used to confirm the presence of carbapenemase production in Enterobacteriaceae?
questions.explanationText:
Ertapenem and Meropenem is the correct answer. Resistance to either of these carbapenems is the most sensitive indicator of carbapenemase production in Enterobacteriaceae. Ertapenem is the most sensitive, but least specific of the two antibiotics.

Cefotaxime and Cefotaxime-clavulanate is incorrect. Both of these antibiotics, when used in combination, are used to detect ESBL producing organisms.

Cefoxitin and Oxacillin is incorrect. Both of these antibiotics are used to detect Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus due to the mecA gene.

Clindamycin and Erythromycin is incorrect. Both of these antibiotics are used to detect inducible clindamycin resistance due to the erm gene in Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species.

questions.questionText: Which of the following tests confirms the presence of Bence-Jones proteinuria:
questions.explanationText:
mmunoelectrophoresis is used to detect the presence of Bence-Jones proteins. Immunoelectrophoresis is used to help detect, diagnose, and monitor the course and treatment of conditions associated with abnormal proteins (such as Bence-Jones), including Multiple Myeloma, Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia, and a few other related diseases.

A Bence Jones protein is a monoclonal globulin protein or immunoglobulin light chain found in the urine, with a molecular weight of 22-24 kDa. Detection of Bence Jones protein may be suggestive of multiple myeloma or Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.
Bence Jones proteins are particularly diagnostic of multiple myeloma.

questions.questionText: Which fungal culture media is used for the primary recovery of pathogenic fungi exclusive of dermatophytes?
questions.explanationText:
Inhibitory mold agar, brain-heart infusion agar with antibiotics and yeast-extract phosphate agar are all used for the primary recovery of pathogenic fungi exclusive of dermatophytes.

Mycosel agar is used for the primary recovery of for the isolation of pathogenic fungi, and is recommended for the recovery of dermatophytes.

Potato flake agar and Sabouraud Dextrose with Brain Heart Infusion agar are used for the primary recovery of saprobic and pathogenic fungi.

Dermatophytes are anamorphic (asexual or imperfect fungi) pathogenic fungus that require keratin for growth. These fungi can cause superficial infections of the hair, skin, and nails, causing ringworms and related diseases. Dermatophytes are spread by direct contact from other people, animals, soil, and from fomites

Dermatophytes are a common label for a group of three types of fungus: Microsporum, Epidermophyton and Trichophyton.

answers.answerText: (SABHI) Sabouraud Dextrose with Brain Heart Infusion agar

questions.questionText: The measurement of sodium and chloride in sweat is the most useful test for the diagnosis of what condition/disease?
questions.explanationText:
Measurement of the sodium and chloride concentration in sweat is the most useful test in the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Significantly elevated concentrations of both ions occur in more than 99% of affected patients.

The definitive test for steatorrhea (failure to digest or absorb fats) is the quantitative fecal fat analysis.

The secretin/CCK (cholecystokinin) test is the direct determination of the exocrine secretory capacity of the pancreas.

Pancreatic cell tumors, which overproduce gastrin, are called gastrinomas; they cause Zollinger-Ellison syndrome and can be duodenal in origin.

answers.answerText: Direct determination of the exocrine secretory capacity of the pancreas.

questions.questionText: Approximately how many doses are required to obtain a steady-state oscillation allowing for peak and trough levels to be evaluated?
questions.explanationText: Approximately five to seven doses are required before a steady-state oscillation is achieved. After the first dose, absorption and distribution occur, followed only by elimination. Before the concentration of drug drops significantly, the second dose is given and the peak of the second dose is additive to what remains of the first dose. The third through the seventh scheduled doses all have the same effect, increasing the serum concentration and the amount eliminated. By the end of the seventh dose, the amount of the drug administered is equal to the amount eliminated during the dosage period. At this point, steady state is established and peak and trough concentrations can be evaluated.

questions.questionText: Parasites that belong to the category Sporozoa are also known as:
questions.explanationText:
Coccidial parasites do not possess specific organelles for locomotion and thus belong to the Sporozoa. Coccidia are a group of protozoal parasites where asexual replication occurs outside of the human host and sexual reproduction occurs inside the human host.

Digenea is a class of parasites that includes the flukes.
Hemoflagellates belong to the Mastigophora and are flagellates found in blood and tissue.

questions.questionText:
An aerobic Gram negative coccobacillus was isolated from a nasopharyngeal swab 48 hours after culture from a 6-month-old with the following culture characteristics on Bordet-Gengou agar:
Small zones of beta-hemolysis; Urease: positive (24 hours); Oxidase: negative; Motility: negative
The MOST probable identification of this isolate is:
questions.explanationText:
Bordetella parapertussis is the correct answer because Bordetella parapertussis can produce a small zone of hemolysis, is urease positive within 24 hours, OXIDASE NEGATIVE, and nonmotile.
Pasteurella multocida is incorrect because this organism is most often isolated from wound infections from cats. This organism is oxidase positive.
Bordetella pertussis is incorrect because this organism is oxidase positive and urease negative.
Bordetella bronchiseptica is incorrect because this organism is oxidase positive, rapid urease positive (4 hours), and motile

questions.questionText: At a minimum, the following class of biological safety cabinet (BSC) must be used when manipulating potential bioterrorism agents and if aerosols are likely:
questions.explanationText:
Class II BSC sterilizes the air in the cabinet and the air to be exhausted. This type of BSC is required for working with aerosols and dangerous, highly virulent organisms such as bioterrorism agents.

Class I BSC allows unsterilized air to flow in and around the material inside. Only the air exhausted is sterilized. It is not sufficient to work with bioterrorism agents.

Class III BSC is completely enclosed with the air being filtered and sterilized as it comes in and as it goes out. Agents requiring this environment also require the worker to use rubber gloves that are attached and sealed to the cabinet.

Class IV BSC does not exist

questions.questionText: Various methods have been employed for detection of Clostridium difficile disease, which method is the gold standard for detection?
questions.explanationText:
Cell cytotoxicity neutralization assays (CCNA) are considered the gold standard for Clostridium difficile detection because it can detect the toxins in the stool sample. However, the assay is labor intensive and requires 48h of incubation for the cells to grow.
Stool culture is very effective in detecting C. difficile, although it requires up to four days to isolate the organism. Isolates must also be subsequently tested for toxin production to prove their causal relationship to disease.

Enzyme immunoassays (EIA) provide a more efficient and rapid means of diagnostic testing. Sensitivity of detection is enhanced by choosing a method that allows for detection of both toxins A and B.

Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are becoming the new gold standard for detection. They determine the presence of toxin A and B genes in a stool sample. It is becoming the new gold standard since it does not need confirmation like other test methods

questions.questionText: The ingredient added to culture media to enhance the recovery of the dimorphic fungi by preventing the overgrowth of more rapidly growing, saprophytic molds is:
questions.explanationText:
Cycloheximide is an antifungal agent that binds to the 80S ribosome of many eukaryotes and prevents protein synthesis by blocking the transfer of RNA to the growing polypeptide chain. The dimorphic fungi have developed resistance to this antifungal agent, and can grow in culture media to which it has been added, in contrast to most rapidly growing saprophytes.

Brain heart infusion is often used as an enrichment to enhance the primary recovery of dimorphic fungi from clinical materials; however, also enhances the growth of other fungal species as well.

Thiamine is an enrichment needed for the growth of a few select fungal species; notably, the dermatophyte Trichophyton tonsurans. It has little influence on the growth of the dimorphic fungi.
Chloramphenicol is added to culture media to prevent the overgrowth of bacteria.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT true about Chloramphenicol?
questions.explanationText: Chloramphenicol is useful to treat a number of bacterial infections.

answers.answerText: Useful to treat a number of fungi infections
It is used as eye ointment to treat conjunctivitis.
It is used as eye ointment to treat conjunctivitis.
It is effective against Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae. and E.coli

questions.questionText: Which of the following statements regarding coagulation disorders is CORRECT?
questions.explanationText:
Clotting factors factors II, VII, IX and X are vitamin K-dependent. Vitamin K plays an important role in coagulation factor synthesis. A lack of vitamin K affects coagulation function.

Although very occasionally a spontaneous mutation can occur, Hemophilia A and B are usually considered inherited disorders.

The liver is the primary site for clotting factor production. Liver damage can cause hemostatic dysfunction.

Inherited factor VIII deficiency (Hemophilia A) and VWF deficiencies are much more common than inherited factor IX deficiency (Hemophilia B).

answers.answerText: Clotting factors II, VII, IX and X are vitamin K-dependent.
Hemophilia A and B are usually acquired disorders.
Damage to the kidneys can cause hemostatic dysfunction as the kidneys are the primary site for clotting factor production.
Factor IX deficiency is the most common inherited coagulation factor deficiency.

questions.questionText: What are key things to remember when collecting a light-blue top tube for coagulation testing?
questions.explanationText:
